data: Four joining marble fragments of a plaque damaged in the upper left corner and below; smooth behind. Combined dimensions given below (thicker towards the upper right). A further fragment from the upper left was seen by Kaibel and Tardia before him, but now lost.
Lines 1-4 are more centred, and there is a space between lines 4 and 5.
A with an upward sloping cross-bar, Ε, Σ, Ω lunate. Traces of guidelines.
Original discovery not recorded; probably from Catania.
Observed by Ferrara among the inscriptions in the house of the Giuseppe Recupero
I.Sicily with the permission of the Assessorato Regionale dei Beni Culturali e dell’Identità Siciliana - Dipartimento dei Beni Culturali e dell’Identità Siciliana
Castello Ursino, Piazza Federico II di Svevia, 95121 Catania (CT)
Inscriptiones Graecae Siciliae et Italiae, additis graecis Galliae Hispaniae, Britanniae, Germaniae inscriptionibus

G. Kaibel, Inscriptiones Graecae Siciliae et Italiae, Additis Graecis Galliae Hispaniae, Britanniae, Germaniae Inscriptionibus, Inscriptiones Graecae Consilio et Auctoritate Academiae Litterarum Regiae Borussicae Editae. Volumen XIV., XIV (Berlin: Georgius Reimerus, 1890)
Le iscrizioni del Museo civico di Catania : storia delle collezioni, cultura epigrafica, edizione
K. Korhonen, Le Iscrizioni Del Museo Civico Di Catania : Storia Delle Collezioni, Cultura Epigrafica, Edizione (Helsinki: Societas Scientiarum Fennica, 2004)
A. Boeckh et al., Corpus Inscriptionum Graecarum, 4 vols. (Berlin: Ex Officina Academica, 1828)
Storia di Catania sino alla fine del secolo xviii
F. Ferrara, Storia Di Catania Sino Alla Fine Del Secolo Xviii (Catania, 1829)
G. Kaibel, Epigrammata Graeca Ex Lapidibus Conlecta (Berolini: G. Reimer, 1878)
Iscrizioni, epigrafi ed epigrammi in Greco della Sicilia orientale di epoca romana
Giacomo Manganaro, “Iscrizioni, epigrafi ed epigrammi in Greco della Sicilia orientale di epoca romana,” Mélanges de l’École Francaise de Rome: Antiquité 106, no. 1 (1994): 79–118
standardisation of template and tidying up encoding
Licensed under a Creative Commons-Attribution 4.0 licence.
Observed by Müller in the Collezione Biscari. Formerly in sala VI.126, now in magazzino del cortile and in magazzino superiore
Encoded following the latest EpiDoc guidelines
James Cummings autogenerated EpiDoc output from database
Alex Antoniou Epidoc editing and English translation
Simona Stoyanova updated list of languages
Marta Fogagnolo revised the text encoding, added the italian translation and the commentary

After ση--- and after κόσμον, Ferrara read a Κ. After κόσμον the upper end of a vertical stroke can be observed (I, K, H). Franz: ση--- | κόσμον [φιλῇ εἶναι] (after ἱδρυσάμην the name of the dedicant follows: e.g. Σή[μων Ξενίου]); Kaibel Epigr. Gr.: Σή[μων], κόσμον [ἐμῇ] πατρ[ίδι]; Kaibel IG: σηκ[ῷ τ’ ἐπὶ] | κόσμον κ[αλὸν ἔθηκα]; Korhonen: σηκ[ῷ τ’ ἐπὶ] κόσμον [αλὸν ἔθηκα?]. Another possibility can be σηκ[ῷ τ’ ἐπὶ] κόσμον [αλὸν ἔτευξα?]
Franz, Kaibel Epigr. Gr.: πατρ[ίδι]; Kaibel IG, Korhonen: πατρ--- (name of the dedicant). The traces after πατρ--- suggest Β, Γ, Ε, Ι, Κ, Μ, Ν, Π.
Korhonen assumed other lines missing after line 5
I raised (a statue of) long-haired Phoebus, far-shooting Apollo, in a sacred enclosure, and added a beautiful decoration. Patr---.
Ho innalzato (una statua di) Febo dai lunghi capelli, lungisaettante Apollo, in un recinto sacro, e ho aggiunto una bella decorazione. Patr---.

The epigram probably accompanied a statue of Apollo. It consisted of two hexameters (Kaibel’s interpretation in Epigr. Gr. of an elegiac distichon is to be rejected), after which the name of the dedicant in prose should follow (---). The epigram has epic echoes, such as the formula  at l. 1 (cf. e.g. Hom. Il. 20.39, Hymn.Ap. 134) and the formula  at l. 2 (cf. e.g. Hom. Il. 1.370, 5.444, 16.711, 17.333): especially the first formula recurs in the variant  in other dedicatory epigrams on stone, cf. IG 4/2, 1 no.433 (= Epigr.ded. 212 Cougny) from Epidaurus (4th CE) and IGUR I no.102b (= Epigr.ded. 247 Cougny) from Rome (2nd-3rd CE).

The inscription is dated palaeographically to the 3rd-4th cent. CE (Manganaro’s dating to the Hellenistic age is to be rejected) and comes probably from Catania, even if the provenance is doubtful, since it was found in a group of inscriptions, of which at least one comes from Syracuse (IG 14, no.58 = ).

Apparatus criticus

  • Text based on photographs;
  • line.1: Ferrara, Franz (from Müller), Kaibel read [Φ]οῖβον
  • lines.3-4: After ση--- and after κόσμον, Ferrara read a Κ. After κόσμον the upper end of a vertical stroke can be observed (I, K, H). Franz: ση--- | κόσμον [φιλῇ εἶναι] (after ἱδρυσάμην the name of the dedicant follows: e.g. Σή[μων Ξενίου]); Kaibel Epigr. Gr.: Σή[μων], κόσμον [ἐμῇ] πατρ[ίδι]; Kaibel IG: σηκ[ῷ τ’ ἐπὶ] | κόσμον κ[αλὸν ἔθηκα]; Korhonen: σηκ[ῷ τ’ ἐπὶ] κόσμον .[αλὸν ἔθηκα?]. Another possibility can be σηκ[ῷ τ’ ἐπὶ] κόσμον .[αλὸν ἔτευξα?]
  • line.5: Franz, Kaibel Epigr. Gr.: πατρ[ίδι]; Kaibel IG, Korhonen: πατρ--- (name of the dedicant). The traces after πατρ--- suggest Β, Γ, Ε, Ι, Κ, Μ, Ν, Π.;
  • Korhonen assumed other lines missing after line 5

English translation

I raised (a statue of) long-haired Phoebus, far-shooting Apollo, in a sacred enclosure, and added a beautiful decoration. Patr---.

Italian translation

Ho innalzato (una statua di) Febo dai lunghi capelli, lungisaettante Apollo, in un recinto sacro, e ho aggiunto una bella decorazione. Patr---.

commentary

The epigram probably accompanied a statue of Apollo. It consisted of two hexameters (Kaibel’s interpretation in Epigr. Gr. of an elegiac distichon is to be rejected), after which the name of the dedicant in prose should follow (Πατρ---). The epigram has epic echoes, such as the formula Φοῖβον ἀκερσεκόμην at l. 1 (cf. e.g. Hom. Il. 20.39, Hymn.Ap. 134) and the formula ἑκατηβόλον Ἀπόλλωνα at l. 2 (cf. e.g. Hom. Il. 1.370, 5.444, 16.711, 17.333): especially the first formula recurs in the variant Φοίβῳ ἀκειρεκόμῃ in other dedicatory epigrams on stone, cf. IG 4/2, 1 no.433 (= Epigr.ded. 212 Cougny) from Epidaurus (4th CE) and IGUR I no.102b (= Epigr.ded. 247 Cougny) from Rome (2nd-3rd CE).

The inscription is dated palaeographically to the 3rd-4th cent. CE (Manganaro’s dating to the Hellenistic age is to be rejected) and comes probably from Catania, even if the provenance is doubtful, since it was found in a group of inscriptions, of which at least one comes from Syracuse (IG 14, no.58 = ISic000875).

The epigram probably accompanied a statue of Apollo. It consisted of two hexameters (Kaibel’s interpretation in Epigr. Gr. of an elegiac distichon is to be rejected), after which the name of the dedicant in prose should follow (Πατρ---). Il. 1.370, 5.444, 16.711, 17.333): especially the first formula recurs in the variant Φοίβῳ ἀκειρεκόμῃ in other dedicatory epigrams on stone, cf.
